# PFAS in Drinking Water

## What are PFAS?
Per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) are synthetic chemicals used in many consumer products. Often called "forever chemicals" because they don't break down naturally.

## California PFAS Regulations

### Notification Levels
- **PFOA**: 5.1 ppt
- **PFOS**: 6.5 ppt
- **PFHxS**: Proposed

### Response Levels
- **PFOA**: 10 ppt
- **PFOS**: 40 ppt

## Testing Requirements
- DDW issued monitoring requirements
- Phased approach by system size
- Results reported publicly

## Sources of PFAS
- Firefighting foam (AFFF)
- Industrial discharges
- Landfills
- Manufacturing facilities
- Military bases

## Treatment Options
- Granular activated carbon (GAC)
- Ion exchange
- Reverse osmosis
- High-pressure membrane filtration

## Resources
- **[DDW PFAS Information](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/PFAS.html)**
- **[EPA PFAS](https://www.epa.gov/pfas)**
- **Local Testing Results**: Check with your water system

## What Residents Can Do
- Request water quality reports
- Consider point-of-use filters (NSF 53 or 58) -- see [DDW Chemical Contaminants](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/Chemicalcontaminants.html) for California standards
- Stay informed about testing results

## Take Action

1. **Check your water for PFAS** -- Request your water system's PFAS testing results or search the [DDW PFAS Information](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/PFAS.html) page for California monitoring data.
2. **Learn about health risks** -- Review the [EPA PFAS page](https://www.epa.gov/pfas) for the latest federal health advisories and regulatory actions on forever chemicals.
3. **Review California standards** -- Visit the [OEHHA Public Health Goals](https://oehha.ca.gov/water/public-health-goals-phgs-drinking-water) page to understand California's health-based PFAS assessments.
4. **Filter your water if concerned** -- Install an NSF 53 or NSF 58-certified filter (granular activated carbon or reverse osmosis) to reduce PFAS levels at home.

# Lead in Drinking Water

## California Lead Standards

### Action Level
- 15 ppb (parts per billion)
- Based on 90th percentile of tap samples

### Public Health Goal
- 0.2 ppb (no safe level established)

## Lead and Copper Rule

### Monitoring
- Tap sampling at high-risk sites
- Schools required to test
- Results reported to [DDW](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/lead-copper-rule/)

### Exceedance Response
- Public notification
- Corrosion control treatment
- Lead service line replacement
- Consumer education

## Sources of Lead
- Lead service lines
- Lead solder (pre-1986)
- Brass fixtures and fittings
- Lead-lined tanks

## Lead in Schools
- [Assembly Bill 746](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/lead-copper-rule/) requires testing
- Action level: 15 ppb
- Remediation required if exceeded
- Results public

## Protecting Yourself

### Reduce Exposure
- Flush pipes before drinking (30 sec - 2 min)
- Use cold water for cooking/drinking
- Consider NSF-certified filter
- Test your home water

### Vulnerable Populations
- Children most at risk
- Pregnant women
- No safe level for children

## Take Action

1. **Test your home water** -- If your home was built before 1986, test for lead. Find a certified lab through [DDW's ELAP program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/labs/).
2. **Learn about the Lead and Copper Rule** -- Visit the [DDW Lead and Copper Rule](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/lead-copper-rule/) page for California's implementation, including school testing requirements.
3. **Review health goals** -- Check the [OEHHA Public Health Goals](https://oehha.ca.gov/water/public-health-goals-phgs-drinking-water) for California's health-based lead assessment (PHG: 0.2 ppb).
4. **Reduce exposure now** -- Flush pipes for 30 seconds to 2 minutes before drinking, use cold water for cooking, and consider an NSF-certified lead filter.

# Arsenic in Drinking Water

## California Arsenic Regulations

### Maximum Contaminant Level (MCL)
- 10 ppb (micrograms per liter)
- Same as federal standard

### Public Health Goal (PHG)
- 0.004 ppb
- Based on cancer risk assessment

## Why the Gap?
The MCL considers:
- Treatment feasibility
- Costs
- Benefits vs risks

The PHG is purely health-based.

## Sources of Arsenic
- Natural geological deposits
- Mining and industrial waste
- Agricultural applications
- Well water often affected

## Health Effects
- Cancer (skin, lung, bladder)
- Cardiovascular effects
- Developmental effects
- Long-term exposure most concerning

## Treatment Options
- Ion exchange
- Activated alumina
- Reverse osmosis
- Coagulation/filtration
- Blending with lower-arsenic water

## Testing
- Required for public water systems
- Private well owners should test
- Labs must be [ELAP certified](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/labs/)

## Resources
- [DDW Chemical Contaminants](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/Chemicalcontaminants.html)
- [EPA arsenic resources](https://www.epa.gov/ground-water-and-drinking-water)
- Local water quality reports

## Take Action

1. **Check your water system's arsenic levels** -- Review your Consumer Confidence Report or search the [DDW Chemical Contaminants](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/Chemicalcontaminants.html) page for arsenic data.
2. **Private well owners: test your water** -- Find an [ELAP-certified lab](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/labs/) and request arsenic testing, especially if you are in an area with natural arsenic deposits.
3. **Understand the standards** -- Review the [OEHHA Public Health Goals](https://oehha.ca.gov/water/public-health-goals-phgs-drinking-water) page to understand the difference between the MCL (10 ppb) and the health-based PHG (0.004 ppb).
4. **Consider treatment** -- If arsenic exceeds the MCL, reverse osmosis or activated alumina filters are effective. Check with your [Regional Board](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/waterboards_map.html) for local guidance.

# Nitrate Contamination in Groundwater

## California Nitrate Standard

### MCL
- 10 mg/L as nitrogen
- 45 mg/L as nitrate

### Health Risk
- Methemoglobinemia (blue baby syndrome)
- Infants under 6 months most vulnerable
- Potential cancer risk (with nitrosamines)

## Sources of Nitrate
- Agricultural fertilizers
- Animal waste (dairies, feedlots)
- Septic systems
- Wastewater treatment
- Natural deposits (some areas)

## Affected Areas in California
- Central Valley (major agricultural area)
- Salinas Valley
- Areas with intensive agriculture
- Communities near dairies

## Monitoring Requirements
- Annual monitoring minimum
- More frequent if elevated
- Vulnerability assessments

## Treatment Options
- Ion exchange
- Reverse osmosis
- Electrodialysis
- Biological denitrification
- Blending

## For Private Well Owners
- Test annually
- Test more often if near agriculture
- Consider treatment if elevated
- Infants should use bottled water if nitrate is high -- see [DDW Chemical Contaminants](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/Chemicalcontaminants.html) for current MCLs

## Prevention
- Fertilizer management practices
- Dairy waste management
- Proper septic system maintenance

## Take Action

1. **Test your well annually** -- If you have a private well near agriculture, test for nitrate at least annually. Find a lab through the [ELAP Certified Labs](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/labs/) directory.
2. **Check your area's groundwater** -- Use the [GAMA Groundwater Information System](https://gamagroundwater.waterboards.ca.gov/gama/gamamap/public/) to see nitrate levels in your region.
3. **Protect infants immediately** -- If nitrate exceeds 10 mg/L (as nitrogen), use bottled water for infant formula. Review the [DDW Chemical Contaminants](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/Chemicalcontaminants.html) page for the current MCL.
4. **Review health standards** -- Visit the [OEHHA Public Health Goals](https://oehha.ca.gov/water/public-health-goals-phgs-drinking-water) page for California's health-based assessment of nitrate risk.

# Chromium-6 (Hexavalent Chromium)

## California's Groundbreaking Standard

California was first state to set a chromium-6 MCL:

### Regulatory History
- 2014: MCL of 10 ppb adopted
- 2017: MCL overturned by court
- Ongoing: New standard development

### Current Status
- No specific chromium-6 MCL in effect
- Total chromium MCL: 50 ppb
- Monitoring continues
- New standard in development

## Health Concerns
- Carcinogen when ingested
- "Erin Brockovich" contaminant
- Long-term exposure concerns

## Sources
- Natural occurrence in some geology
- Industrial discharges
- PG&E contamination sites
- Chrome plating operations

## Public Health Goal
- 0.02 ppb
- Based on cancer risk

## Treatment Options
- Strong base anion exchange
- Reduction and coagulation
- Reverse osmosis
- Specialized treatment systems

## Finding Information
- [DDW Chemical Contaminants page](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/Chemicalcontaminants.html)
- Water system [Consumer Confidence Reports](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/CCR.html)
- Local testing data

## Take Action

1. **Check your water's chromium-6 levels** -- Review your utility's [Consumer Confidence Report](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/CCR.html) or request chromium-6 test data directly.
2. **Review California standards** -- Visit the [DDW Chemical Contaminants](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/Chemicalcontaminants.html) page for the latest on total chromium MCL (50 ppb) and the chromium-6 standard development.
3. **Understand the health goal** -- Check the [OEHHA Public Health Goals](https://oehha.ca.gov/water/public-health-goals-phgs-drinking-water) page for the PHG of 0.02 ppb and the cancer risk assessment.
4. **Consider treatment** -- If concerned, reverse osmosis systems are effective at removing chromium-6 at the point of use. Look for NSF 58-certified systems.

# Disinfection Byproducts (DBPs)

## What are DBPs?
Chemicals formed when disinfectants react with natural organic matter in water.

## Regulated DBPs

### Trihalomethanes (THMs)
- **MCL**: 80 ppb
- Includes chloroform, bromoform, others
- Cancer risk with long-term exposure

### Haloacetic Acids (HAAs)
- **MCL**: 60 ppb
- Five regulated acids (HAA5)
- Associated with health effects

## Why DBPs Form
- Chlorine + organic matter = THMs
- Chloramine reduces THMs but forms other DBPs
- Source water quality matters

## Monitoring Requirements
- Quarterly for larger systems
- Annual for smaller systems
- Location-based sampling

## Reducing DBPs

### System Level
- Remove organics before disinfection
- Optimize disinfection process
- Alternative disinfectants
- Enhanced coagulation

### At Home
- Activated carbon filters remove some DBPs -- check [DDW Chemical Contaminants](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/Chemicalcontaminants.html) for California's DBP standards
- Point-of-use treatment
- Proper ventilation (volatilization during showers)

## Balancing Act
Must balance:
- Adequate disinfection (kill pathogens)
- DBP minimization (reduce chemical risk)
- Microbial risk generally more immediate

## Take Action

1. **Review your CCR for DBP levels** -- Check your annual [Consumer Confidence Report](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/CCR.html) for THM and HAA5 results compared to their MCLs (80 ppb and 60 ppb respectively).
2. **Learn about the regulations** -- Visit the [DDW Chemical Contaminants](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/Chemicalcontaminants.html) page for California's DBP standards and monitoring requirements.
3. **Understand health risks** -- Review the [OEHHA Public Health Goals](https://oehha.ca.gov/water/public-health-goals-phgs-drinking-water) for health-based assessments of individual THMs and HAAs.
4. **Reduce home exposure** -- Install an activated carbon filter to remove some DBPs, and ventilate bathrooms during showers to reduce inhalation of volatile compounds.

# 1,2,3-Trichloropropane (TCP)

## California-Specific Contaminant

### MCL
- 5 ppt (parts per trillion)
- California-specific standard
- One of lowest MCLs ever set

### Why So Low?
- Potent carcinogen
- No federal standard exists
- California PHG: 0.7 ppt

## Sources
- Soil fumigant impurity (historical)
- Products like Shell D-D and Dow Telone
- Used 1950s-1980s in agriculture
- Contaminated Central Valley groundwater

## Affected Areas
- Central Valley extensively affected
- Agricultural regions
- Hundreds of water systems impacted

## Funding for Cleanup
- [Proposition 68](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/grants_loans/) provided funding
- [SAFER funding](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/safer/) available
- Many systems need treatment

## Treatment Options
- Granular activated carbon (GAC)
- Air stripping
- Advanced oxidation processes
- Often requires specialized treatment

## System Challenges
- Detection at ppt levels challenging
- Treatment expensive
- Ongoing monitoring required
- Small systems particularly burdened

## Take Action

1. **Check if your water system is affected** -- Review the [DDW Chemical Contaminants](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/Chemicalcontaminants.html) page for TCP monitoring data and California's 5 ppt MCL.
2. **Look up funding options** -- Visit the [SAFER Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/safer/) to see if your water system qualifies for treatment funding.
3. **Review health standards** -- Check the [OEHHA Public Health Goals](https://oehha.ca.gov/water/public-health-goals-phgs-drinking-water) page for the TCP PHG of 0.7 ppt and the cancer risk basis.
4. **Private well owners: test your water** -- If you are in the Central Valley or an agricultural area, request TCP testing from an [ELAP-certified lab](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/labs/).

# Uranium in Drinking Water

## California Uranium Standards

### MCL
- 20 pCi/L (picocuries per liter)
- Or 30 Î¼g/L (micrograms per liter)

### Natural Occurrence
- Common in certain California geology
- Sierra Nevada foothills
- Coastal Range areas
- Desert regions

## Health Effects

### Chemical Toxicity
- Kidney damage (primary concern)
- Occurs at lower levels than radiation effects

### Radiological Effects
- Cancer risk at high levels
- Less immediate than chemical toxicity

## Monitoring Requirements
- Part of radionuclide monitoring
- Frequency based on vulnerability
- [ELAP-certified lab](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/labs/) required

## Treatment Options
- Ion exchange
- Reverse osmosis
- Enhanced coagulation
- Activated alumina

## Private Well Concerns
- Test if in affected geology -- use the [GAMA Groundwater Information System](https://gamagroundwater.waterboards.ca.gov/gama/gamamap/public/) to check your area
- No monitoring requirements
- Treatment responsibility on owner

## Related Contaminants
- Gross alpha monitoring
- Radium
- Radon (not currently regulated in California)

## Take Action

1. **Check your area for uranium** -- Search the [GAMA Groundwater Information System](https://gamagroundwater.waterboards.ca.gov/gama/gamamap/public/) to see if uranium has been detected in your region.
2. **Review your water system's data** -- Check your [Consumer Confidence Report](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/CCR.html) for radionuclide monitoring results.
3. **Private well owners: test your water** -- If you live in Sierra foothills, Coastal Range, or desert areas, test for uranium through an [ELAP-certified lab](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/labs/).
4. **Learn about health standards** -- Visit the [DDW Chemical Contaminants](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/Chemicalcontaminants.html) page for the current MCL of 20 pCi/L and treatment options.

# Perchlorate Contamination

## California Perchlorate Standard

### MCL
- 6 ppb (micrograms per liter)
- California-specific (no federal MCL)

### Health Concern
- Interferes with thyroid function
- Affects iodine uptake
- Developmental concerns

## Sources of Perchlorate

### Primary Sources
- Rocket fuel manufacturing
- Fireworks
- Explosives
- Road flares
- Fertilizers (Chilean nitrate)

### Contaminated Areas
- Near aerospace facilities
- Military installations
- Industrial sites
- Affected groundwater basins

## Notable California Sites
- San Gabriel Valley
- Inland Empire
- Santa Clara Valley
- Near military bases

## Monitoring
- Required for public water systems
- Vulnerability assessments
- Entry point monitoring

## Treatment
- Ion exchange (selective resins)
- Biological treatment
- Reverse osmosis
- Specialized perchlorate treatment

## Resources
- [DTSC cleanup sites](https://www.envirostor.dtsc.ca.gov)
- Regional Water Board information
- [GeoTracker database](https://geotracker.waterboards.ca.gov)
- Water system reports

## Take Action

1. **Check for nearby contamination** -- Search the [GeoTracker database](https://geotracker.waterboards.ca.gov) and [DTSC EnviroStor](https://www.envirostor.dtsc.ca.gov) for perchlorate cleanup sites near you.
2. **Review your water quality** -- Check your utility's [Consumer Confidence Report](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/CCR.html) for perchlorate monitoring results against California's 6 ppb MCL.
3. **Understand health impacts** -- Visit the [OEHHA Public Health Goals](https://oehha.ca.gov/water/public-health-goals-phgs-drinking-water) page for California's health-based perchlorate assessment and thyroid-related concerns.
4. **Consider treatment** -- If perchlorate is detected above the MCL, point-of-use reverse osmosis systems are effective. Contact your [Regional Board](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/waterboards_map.html) for local guidance.

# Bacteria and Pathogens in Water

## Microbial Contaminants

### Total Coliform Rule
- Indicator of sanitary quality
- No more than 5% positive samples/month
- Triggers follow-up testing

### E. coli
- Indicates fecal contamination
- Any presence triggers action
- Acute health risk

### Turbidity
- Cloudiness measurement
- Indicates treatment effectiveness
- Surface water treatment requirement

## Treatment Requirements

### Surface Water
- Must achieve specified pathogen reduction
- Giardia: 99.9% removal
- Viruses: 99.99% removal
- Cryptosporidium: Treatment technique required

### Groundwater
- Under Direct Influence (GWUDI) treated as surface
- Disinfection required unless exempted
- Monitoring for fecal indicators

## Disinfection Methods
- Chlorination (most common)
- Chloramines
- Ozone
- UV disinfection
- Chlorine dioxide

## Boil Water Advisories

### When Issued
- Loss of disinfection
- Main breaks with contamination
- Positive E. coli tests
- System pressure loss

### What to Do
- Boil water 1 minute
- Use bottled water
- Follow utility instructions and check the [DDW Drinking Water Programs](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/programs/) page for active advisories
- Wait for all-clear

## Take Action

1. **Check your system's compliance** -- Visit the [DDW Drinking Water Programs](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/programs/) page to see if your water system has any active microbial violations or advisories.
2. **Review the Total Coliform Rule** -- Learn about monitoring requirements at the [DDW Revised Total Coliform Rule](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/rtcr.html) page.
3. **Private well owners: test annually** -- Get bacteria testing from an [ELAP-certified lab](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/labs/) at least once per year.
4. **During boil water advisories** -- Boil water for 1 minute (3 minutes above 6,500 feet), use bottled water, or use an NSF-certified absolute 1-micron filter. Check the [EPA Emergency Disinfection Guide](https://www.epa.gov/ground-water-and-drinking-water/emergency-disinfection-drinking-water) for detailed instructions.
